chapter.title: &buildah; Overview
chapter.para: &buildah; is tool for building OCI-compliant container images. &buildah; makes it possible to perform the following actions.

listitem.para: Create containers from scratch, or from an existing image.
Create an image from a working container or using Dockerfile.
Build images in the OCI image format or the traditional upstream &deng; image format.
Mount a working container's root filesystem for manipulation.
Use the updated contents of a container's root filesystem as a filesystem layer to create a new image.
Delete a working container or an image and rename a local container.

chapter.para: Compared to &deng;, &buildah; has several important advantages.

listitem.para: &buildah; adheres the UNIX philosophy by focusing only on one task: building container images.
The tool makes it possible to mount a working container's filesystem, so it becomes accessible by host.
The process of building container images using &buildah; can be automated using scripts.
Similar to &podman;, &buildah; supports the rootless mode.
It is possible to build images inside a container without mounting the &docker; socket, which improves security.

sect2.title: &podman; and &buildah;
sect2.para: &podman; and &buildah; are complimentary tools for working with OCI images and containers. While &buildah; focuses on building images, &podman; offers commands and functions for maintaining and modifying images. It also makes it possible to create, run, and maintain containers created from images. Although &podman; allows you to build images via Dockerfile, it uses &buildah;'s golang API to accomplish that.

sect1.title: &buildah; Installation
sect1.para: To install &buildah;, run the sudo zypper in buildah. Run then buildah --version to check whether &buildah; has been installed successfully.
